properties.Name: Qweqw'ópelhp
properties.Description:
Common Name: Seabird Island or Maria Island
Halq'eméylem: Qweqw'ópelhp (First People’s Cultural Council 2020)
Pronounciation: s-q'ə'w-qəl (Galloway 1993, 653)
Meaning: 'river turn at the head' (Galloway 1993, 653)
a.k.a.: Kwakwapilt First Nation, Seabird Island Reserve.
First Voices: Elizabeth Herrling 2016


Video:
Qw'emqw'em li te Sq'ewqel. Growing up on Seabird told by Ts'ats'elexwot (Elizabeth Herrling)


Description:
Kwakwapilt First Nation (First People’s Cultural Council 2020). Seabird Island Reserve (GeoBC 2014)

Territory: Tait

Informant Quote: 'He picked that island so he could build his house on it' - Elizabeth Herrling 2016 (First People’s Cultural Council 2020).

Accuracy (1-5): 5; Google Maps, Seabird Island Reserve (GeoBC 2014), Galloway 1993 map

Time: 1965,1993, 2015, 2020

ID Key: LMIS02

Reference:
First People’s Cultural Council. 2020. 'Halq’eméylem Words'. Place Names Halq’eméylem | FirstVoices’ Language for Place Names. [Audio]. 24 September 2020. https://www.firstvoices.com/explore/FV/sections/Data/Salish/Halkomelem/Halq'em%C3%A9ylem/learn/words/categories/16c0cb8d-74e7-4743-8403-dc759069cf94

Galloway, Brent Douglas. 1993. A Grammar of Upriver Halkomelem. University of California Press. [Map Upriver Halkomelem Dialect Area]. https://doi.org/10.1525/9780520945180

Herring, Elizabeth. 2015. Shxweli- Seabird. Qw’emqw’em Li Te Sq’ewqel. Growing up on Seabird. Part 1. [Video]. Told by Ts’ats’elexwot (Elizabeth Herrling). https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vtlBbymHw-U&t=10s

Wells, Oliver N. 1965. A Vocabulary of Native Words in the Halkomelem Language as Used by The Native People of the Lower Fraser Valley, B.C. https://archive.org/details/vocabularyofnati0000well/mode/2up

properties.Name: Sasquatch Provincial Park
properties.Description:
Common Name: Sásq'ets (Galloway 2009, 807, 1292)
Halq'eméylem: sε'sxač (Duff 1952, 118); Sásq'ets (Galloway 2009, 807, 1292)
Pronounciation: n/a
Meaning: Wild hairy man
a.k.a.: Sasquatch

Video:
Kelsey Charlie from Sts'ailes; BC Was Awesome host Bob Kronbauer


Description:
east of Harrison Hotsprings; 'The most famous slalakum ('strange unnatural creatures'), is the hairy giant sasquatch (sε'sxač)' (Duff 1952, 118); stl'á:leqem Sásq'ets (Galloway 2009, 807, 1292)

Territory: Chehalis

Informant Quote: 'Sasquatches are usually seen singly. They are described as men, covered with dark fur, more than 8 feet tall, who leave footprints about 20 inches long.' (Duff 1952, 118)
E.L. is Edmond Lorenzetto, 55, lived whole life at Ohamil or Katz, both parents and grandparents from same area, a Spaniard married Grandmother giving surname (Duff 1952, 9).

Accuracy (1-5): 1; Sasquatch have been sited in different locations in Chehalis; Sasquatch Provincial Park location in high area (Google Earth 2020)

Time: 1952, 2009, 2019, 2020

ID Key: SM03

Reference:
Duff, Wilson. 1952. The Upper Stalo Indians Of The Fraser River Of B.C. Anthropology in British Columbia, Memoir No.1, Victoria, BC: British Columbia Provincial Royal Museum.

Galloway, Brent Douglas. 2009. Dictionary of Upriver Halkomelem. University of California Press. https://doi.org/10.1525/9780520945180

Google Earth v 7.3.3.7786. 2020. Lower Fraser Valley. Eye Altitude 71.53 km. SIO, NOAA, U.S. Navy, NGA, GEBCO, Landsat, Copernicus. Digital Globe 2020. https://www.google.com/earth/versions/#earth-pro

Kronbauer, Bob. 2019. 'The real story of Sasquatch'. [Video. 5:02]. BC Was Awesome, Vancouver Is Awesome. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K7frmKcM3JU

properties.Name: Harrison Lake
properties.Description:
Common Name: Harrison Lake
Halq'eméylem: Qwols Qo (Ts'ats'elexwot Elizabeth Herrling 2007)
Pronounciation: Qwols Qo (Ts'ats'elexwot Elizabeth Herrling 2007)
Meaning: unknown
a.k.a.: n/a

Video:
Ts'ats'elexwot Elizabeth Herrling 2007


Description:
At a logging camp at Harrison Lake, near the water and a sandy beach (Ts'ats'elexwot Elizabeth Herrling 2007)

Territory: Chehalis

Informant Quote: 'We were at home one day, a men came walking into camp, packing two little bears. They were real small. Their mother must have discarded them. So he took them home. So we had to look after them.' (Ts'ats'elexwot Elizabeth Herrling 2007)


Accuracy (1-5): 2; Location not known, point in middle of Harrison Lake, but story would be on the shore somewhere.

Time: 2007

ID Key: LMLK04

Reference:
Ts’ats’elexwot Elizabeth Herrling (StoryTeller), Burton, Strong (Editor), and Jared (Illustrator). 2007. Shxweli- Baby Bear. [Video 4:43]. https://www.youtube.com/embed/8n59taQiDNE

properties.Name: Səmε'ɬ
properties.Description:
Common Name: Sumas Lake
Halq'eméylem: Səmε'ɬ (Duff 1952, 23); Semá:th (First People’s Cultural Council 2020)
Pronounciation: sum–AHL (Wells 1965)
Meaning: unknown
a.k.a.: n/a
First Voices: Elizabeth Phillips 2016


Video:
Lumlamelut Laura Wee Lay Laq




Description:
A shallow, large lake located between Sumas Mountain and the northern Cascades (Duff 1952).

Territory: Sumas

Informant Quote: n/a

Accuracy (1-5): 2; Galloway map shows bed of drained lake nestled between Sumas Mtn and Vedder Mtn (1993).

Time: 1952, 1965, 1993, 2020

ID Key: LMLK08

Reference:
Duff, Wilson. 1952. The Upper Stalo Indians Of The Fraser River Of B.C. Anthropology in British Columbia, Memoir No.1, Victoria, BC: British Columbia Provincial Royal Museum.

First People’s Cultural Council. 2020. 'Halq’eméylem Words'. Place Names Halq’eméylem | FirstVoices’ Language for Place Names. [Audio]. 24 September 2020. https://www.firstvoices.com/explore/FV/sections/Data/Salish/Halkomelem/Halq'em%C3%A9ylem/learn/words/categories/16c0cb8d-74e7-4743-8403-dc759069cf94

Galloway, Brent Douglas. 1993. A Grammar of Upriver Halkomelem. University of California Press. [Map 2. Upriver Halkomelem Dialect Area]. https://doi.org/10.1525/9780520945180

The Reach. 2020. Semá:Th X̱ó:Tsa: Sts’ólemeqwelh Sx̱ó:Tsa (Great Gramma’s Lake). [Video 13:50] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kGRTZqWwkKs.

The Reach. 2020. Semá:th Xo:tsa: Halq'eméylem Pronunciation Guide. [Video. 2:34]. [Semá:th Xo:tsa Exibition]. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FJoKS9YyU5w

Wells, Oliver N. 1965. A Vocabulary of Native Words in the Halkomelem Language as Used by The Native People of the Lower Fraser Valley, B.C. https://archive.org/details/vocabularyofnati0000well/mode/2up
